questions.text:
A 42-year-old obese woman has elevated AST and ALT levels, normal bilirubin, and imaging showing hepatic steatosis, with no other significant laboratory findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?

AST - 80 IU/L
ALT - 100 IU/L
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, an obese patient with elevated AST and ALT levels, normal bilirubin levels and imaging revealing hepatic steatosis, with no other significant laboratory findings is likely to be diagnosed with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease(NAFLD). NAFLD is characterised by hepatic steatosis, absence of significant alcohol consumption (<20g/day) and no other liver disease etiologies. AST:ALT being 0.8 (<1) also points towards NAFLD.

Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) is defined as hepatic steatosis in the absence of any secondary cause for fat accumulation. Histologically, this requires fat accumulation in more than 5% of hepatocytes and it can be divided into:

  • Nonalcoholic fatty liver (NAFL)- steatosis without inflammation
  • Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) - steatosis with inflammation

NAFLD is strongly associated with obesity and insulin resistance. Its diagnosis requires a demonstration of hepatic steatosis and exclusion of significant alcohol consumption and other causes of hepatic fat accumulation. 

AST:ALT ratio <1 is seen in NAFLD (nonalcoholic fatty liver disease).

The AST:ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:

AST:ALT Condition
<1
Chronic viral hepatitis, Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease
>1 Cirrhosis
>2:1 Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease. Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.
>3:1
Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease.

  
Other options:

Option B: Alcoholic liver disease is characterised by significant alcohol consumption, often with elevated gamma-glutamyl transferase (GGT).

Option C: Chronic hepatitis C is associated with the presence of HCV antibodies, along with elevated liver enzymes and elevated bilirubin levels.

Option D: Autoimmune hepatitis is characterised by elevated liver enzymes, the presence of autoantibodies (ANA, ASMA, etc), and interface hepatitis on biopsy.

questions.text: A long standing diabetic presents with abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence and diarrhea. She has also had weight loss and megaloblastic anemia. Her Hydrogen Breath test is positive. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Rifaximin is an antibiotic that is specifically effective against the types of bacteria commonly associated with SIBO.

Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth - SIBO can be caused by strictures, surgery, DM, scleroderma, AIDS. It is characterized by symptoms of malabsorption: diarrhea, flatulence, weightloss, anemia in chronic cases - particularly megaloblastic anemia due to reduced B12 and high folate levels. Diagnosis is by endoscopy with jejunal aspirate (shows > 105 microorgansims) and glucose hydrogen breath test.

Treatment is a 7-day course of Rifaximin/Amoxiclav and a high-fat, low-carbohydrate diet. Surgery is often the best option for conditions like blind loops, strictures, diverticula, or afferent loops. However, surgery cannot be used to treat functional stasis caused by scleroderma or other conditions. For these cases, broad-spectrum antibiotics are appropriate. Other treatment options for SIBO include dietary modifications and probiotics. Probiotics can help restore the balance of bacteria in the gut, which may improve symptoms of SIBO. A low-FODMAP diet is a type of diet that eliminates certain types of carbohydrates that can be difficult to digest for people with SIBO.

Options B, C and D: Clarithromycin is usually used for H. pylori, and is not as effective as rifaximin. 5-ASA and budesonide are anti-inflammatory drugs effective for IBD.

questions.text:
An elderly lady presented with weight gain. On examination, her limbs appeared thin, and her blood pressure was 180/100 mm Hg. She is also noticed to have the following findings, as shown in the image below. Her lab investigation findings are given below. This condition is likely to be due to
  • 24h urinary free cortisol- elevated 
  • Plasma cortisol after administration of 1mg dexamethasone - elevated
  • Plasma ACTH levels- elevated
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone test- negative
  • High-dose dexamethasone test- negative
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario, along with the image showing buffalo hump, central obesity, and purple stretch marks, is suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. It is likely to be due to ectopic adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) production.

Cushing's syndrome refers to a group of clinical features that result from chronic exposure to excess glucocorticoids. It can be ACTH-dependent or ACTH-independent.

Clinical features of Cushing’s syndrome are attributed to the increased glucocorticoid, mineralocorticoid, and sex steroid actions of cortisol. They include:

System Clinical features
Body fat
  • Central or truncal obesity (most common)
  • Buffalo hump (fat deposition behind the neck)
  • Moon facies  
Skin
  • Purple striae (over abdomen & flanks)
  • Acne and Hirsutism 
  • Easy bruising 
  • Facial plethora
  • Hyperpigmentation 
Musculoskeletal
  • Proximal myopathy
  • Osteoporosis
Metabolic
  • Poorly controlled hyperglycemia
  • Dyslipidemia
Reproductive
  • Oligomenorrhea
  • Amenorrhea
Renal
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
CVS
  • Atherosclerosis 
  • Diastolic Hypertension 
  • Edema 
  • Hypertension
Hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable state 
  • Lymphopenia
  • Neutrophilia
  • Eosinopenia
CNS
  • Depression
  • Psychosis 
  • Anxiety

The image given below shows the clinical features seen in Cushing's syndrome.

Once Cushing's syndrome is suspected, laboratory investigations are useful in the diagnosis. Patients will have elevated 24-hour urinary cortisol levels; they have elevated levels of plasma cortisol, which are not suppressed by dexamethasone. If these are elevated, it confirms that the patient has elevated levels of cortisol.

The next step is to evaluate if the elevated cortisol levels are due to elevated ACTH or are independent of ACTH levels. In this patient, the ACTH levels are elevated, which means that increased ACTH has caused increased production of cortisol. Increased ACTH can be due to a pituitary tumor that produces ACTH or ectopic ACTH production that is seen in tumors like bronchial or pancreatic carcinoids, medullary thyroid carcinoma, etc.

The source of ACTH production can be identified using an MRI of the pituitary, a corticotropin-releasing hormone test, and a high-dose dexamethasone test. If the ACTH production is due to an adenoma in the pituitary, it responds to the administration of corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH) and is suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone. In this patient, both of these tests are negative, which means that ACTH production is not from the pituitary but is due to ectopic production of ACTH. The patient has to be evaluated for underlying tumours. 

Other options:

Option A: Pituitary adenoma has elevated levels of cortisol and is normal to high ACTH levels. The pituitary MRI might show the presence of a tumor. CRH test and high-dose dexamethasone tests are positive.

Option B: In bilateral adrenal hyperplasia, there are increased levels of cortisol. However, the ACTH levels are low due to negative feedback to the hypothalamus and pituitary.

Option C: In adrenocortical adenoma also, cortisol levels are associated with a decrease in ACTH levels.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: Identify the incorrectly matched pair for the type of motor neuron disorder.
questions.solution:
Progressive muscular atrophy is a progressive isolated lower motor neuron disorder (LMN).

Some patients develop upper motor neuron signs later in their clinical course, at which point the disease is called lower motor neuron-onset ALS.

Other options:

Option A: Primary lateral sclerosis: It is a progressive, isolated upper motor neuron disorder (UMN)
Some patients develop lower motor neuron signs later in their clinical course, at which point the disease is called upper motor neuron-onset ALS

Option B: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS): It is the most common form of motor neuron disease.
Includes upper and lower motor neuron pathology (UMN +LMN)

Option D: Progressive bulbar palsy: It is a progressive upper and lower motor neuron (UMN +LMN) disorder of cranial muscles.
This condition may occasionally stay isolated to the bulbar segment, but more commonly, upper and lower motor neuron signs and symptoms spread to involve other segments. This is then referred to as bulbar-onset ALS. Progressive bulbar palsy is also known as spinal muscular atrophy.

questions.text: Thrombolysis can be considered in a case of ischemic stroke for all of these situations, except _________.
questions.solution:
Thrombolysis is contraindicated in recent history of head injury.

Thrombolysis refers to the dissolution of the intravascular clots to prevent ischemic damage and improve blood flow. 

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (dose 0.9 mg/kg) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text:
You are the intern posted in the emergency department. You came across an ABG report given below. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this change?

pH: 7.50
PaCO2: 28 mm of Hg
HCO3-: 24 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given ABG report shows increased blood arterial pH(Normal range: 7.35-7.45), decreased PaCO2(Normal: 35 - 45 mmHg) and normal HCO3 levels(Normal: 22-28 mEq/L) indicating respiratory alkalosis.The most likely cause of respiratory alkalosis is panic disorder, which causes hyperventilation.

Metabolic disorders

Conditions Features Etiology
Metabolic acidosis

There is decreased blood arterial pH because of an increase in endogenous acid production (Example: Diabetic ketoacidosis, increased lactate in sepsis), loss of HCO3- (Example: diarrhoea), or low excretion of net acid by kidneys (Example: chronic kidney disease). Respiratory compensation (alveolar hyperventilation) occurs causing a decrease in PaCO2.

High anionic metabolic acidosis

  • Methanol
  • Uremia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol
  • Iron tablets
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Salicylates (Late)

Normal anionic gap metabolic acidosis

  • Hyperalimentation
  • Addison's disease
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Diarrhea
  • Acetazolamide
  • Spironolactone
  • Saline infusion
Metabolic alkalosis

There is increased blood arterial pH, as a result of a net gain of HCO3- or a loss of nonvolatile acid from the extracellular fluid. Compensatory alveolar hypoventilation occurs and causes an increase in PaCO2. 

Loss of hydrogen:

  • Gastrointestinal loss
    • Removal of gastric secretions- vomiting or nasogastric suction
    • Chloride-losing diarrhea
    • Gastrocolic fistula
    • Villous adenoma
    • Antacid therapy, particularly if combined with cation exchange resin
  • Renal loss
    • Loop or thiazide diuretics
    • Mineralocorticoid excess (primary aldosteronism, Cushing's, steroids, licorice)
    • Posthypercapnic states
    • Hypercalcemia, including the milk-alkali syndrome
  • H+ movement into cells
    • Hypokalemia

Exogenous Alkali:

  • Administration of NaHCO3, sodium citrate/gluconate/acetate/antacids
  • Massive blood transfusion
  • Antacids- Milk alkali syndrome

Contraction alkalosis (loss of ECF volume):

  • Loop or thiazide-type diuretics
  • Sweat losses in cystic fibrosis
  • Gastric losses in achlorhydria

Miscellaneous:

  • Bartter's syndrome
  • Gitelman's syndrome
Respiratory acidosis

There is decreased blood arterial pH as a result of an increase in PaCO2 following alveolar hypoventilation.
  • Central: Stroke, infection
  • Airway: Obstruction, Asthma
  • Lung Parenchyma: Emphysema, Pneumoconiosis, Bronchitis
  • Neuromuscular: Muscular dystrophies, Myasthenia
  • Obesity
  • Hypoventilation
Respiratory alkalosis

There is an increase in blood arterial pH due to a decrease in PaCO2 due to alveolar hyperventilation.

Hyperventilation

  • Anxiety/panic attack
  • Hypoxemia( eg: High altitude)
  • Salicylates (Early)
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Tumor

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in patients with Zieve's syndrome?
questions.solution:
Zieve's syndrome is not associated with thrombocytosis.

Zieve's syndrome is a rare syndrome occurring due to severe alcoholic hepatitis characterized by a triad of:

  • Cholestatic jaundice
  • Hemolytic anemia
  • Transient hyperlipidemia

It resolves with abstinence from alcohol.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with distal leg weakness reduced muscle stretch reflexes, with no complaints of tingling or numbness. On examination, there is atrophy of the muscles below the knee. The following clinical findings are seen. The most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The given image shows muscle atrophy, high arch of the foot, and hammer-toes, which, along with the other clinical features mentioned above, are suggestive of Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

Charcot–Marie–Tooth disease (CMT) is the most common type of hereditary neuropathy. CMT is a syndrome of many genetically distinct disorders.

CMT type 1 is the most common form of hereditary neuropathy. It usually presents in the first to third decade of life with distal leg weakness, e.g., foot drop. The following findings are seen:

  • No numbness or tingling
  • Reduced sensation to all modalities apparent on examination
  • Reduced muscle stretch reflexes
  • Atrophy of the muscles below the knee, leading to inverted champagne bottle legs 

Diabetic neuropathy, primary amyloidosis, neuropathy associated with Sjogren’s syndrome, and rheumatoid arthritis are acquired forms of neuropathies.

Other options:

Option B- Refsum's disease is a hereditary disorder of lipid metabolism. They can manifest in infancy to early adulthood with classic tetrad of:

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Cerebellar ataxia
  • Elevated CSF protein concentration

They have elevated serum phytanic acid, and they are autosomal recessive. 

Option C- Sjogren syndrome is a chronic, slowly progressing autoimmune disease characterized by lymphocytic infiltration of the exocrine glands. Predominately seen in middle-aged women. The majority of them present with impaired lacrimal and salivary gland function. Neuropathy associated with Sjogren's syndrome is either sensory or sensorimotor polyneuropathy like mononeuritis multiplex and myelitis.

Option D- Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory disease characterized by symmetric polyarthritis. The incidence increases between the ages of 25 and 55 years. Chronic inflammation of the ankle and midtarsal regions leads to pes planovalgus or flat feet. Other deformities seen in RA are: 

  • Swan-neck deformity
  • Boutonniere deformity
  • Z-line deformity

Related Pearl: Neuropathic Disorders

Hereditary neuropathic disorders 

  • Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (Most common hereditary neuropathy)
  • Tangier disease
  • Friedreich’s ataxia
  • Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathy
  • Hereditary Neuropathy with Liability to Pressure Palsies (HNPP)
  • Hereditary Neuralgic Amyotrophy (HNA)
  • Hereditary Sensory and Autonomic Neuropathy (HSAN)
  • Fabry’s disease (angiokeratoma corporis diffusum)
  • Refsum’s disease

Causes of acquired neuropathies

  • Primary or AL amyloidosis
  • Diabetic neuropathy
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Sjögren’s syndrome
  • Rheumatoid arthritis (RA)
  • Scleroderma, Sarcoidosis
  • Infectious (VZV,CMV,EBV,Hepatitis, HIV, Diphtheria, Leprosy) 
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP)
 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male patient with a history of fatiguability, weight gain, cold intolerance, and thick, dry skin for the last 6 months. He was brought to the casualty with reduced consciousness level, hypothermia, bradycardia, and hypotension and a recent history of pneumonia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history suggests of a typical case of hypothyroidism, and the likely diagnosis is myxedema coma.

Myxedema coma is a severe neurological complication of hypothyroidism. It is mostly seen in the elderly and has a high mortality rate of 20-40%. It is often precipitated by:

  • Drugs like sedatives, antidepressants, anaesthetics
  • Infections like pneumonia
  • Congestive heart failure, myocardial ischemia
  • Cerebrovascular accidents
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Exposure to cold

All these cause hypoventilation, leading to hypoxia and hypercapnia. 

Clinical features include a reduced level of consciousness, seizures, hypothermia (can reach 23°C), metabolic disturbances, and symptoms and signs of hypothyroidism (fatiguability, cold intolerance, thick dry skin, weight gain, constipation, etc).

Management of myxedema coma involves:

  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • Levothyroxine (T4): Single loading IV dose (200-400 mcg) and maintenance oral dose (1.6 mcg/kg/day)
    • Liothyronine (T3): Added along with T4 either via nasogastric tube or IV 
    • Parenteral hydrocortisone (50 mg every 6 h): Given to correct the impaired levels of corticoid hormones
    • Broad-spectrum IV antibiotics: Given in case of infections
  • Supportive therapy:
    • Hypertonic saline or IV glucose if severe hyponatremia or hypoglycemia is present
    • External warming if body temperature is <30° to prevent circulatory collapse and use of space blankets to prevent heat loss
    • Ventilatory support with regular blood-gas analysis in the first 48 h
    • Avoidance of hypotonic fluids to prevent fluid retention

Other options:

Option A: Septic shock occurs due to systemic infections like bacterial and fungal infections, toxic shock syndrome, pancreatitis etc, massive trauma, and severe burns, resulting in fatal organ failure. Massive release of inflammatory cytokines causes peripheral vasodilation and pooling, which causes the skin to look flushed. Vascular damage, DIC, and alveolar damage (shock lung) can be seen.

Option B: Cardiogenic shock occurs due to myocardial pump failure, resulting in low cardiac output. It is associated with conditions like myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, cardiac tamponade, and pulmonary embolism. Patients present with hypotension, a weak rapid pulse, tachypnea, and cool clammy skin.

Option D: Hypoglycemia occurs due to insulin or insulin-producing drugs used to treat diabetes mellitus or other substances like alcohol. It is characterised by low plasma glucose levels and relief of symptoms after normalization of plasma glucose levels. Along with neurological symptoms (behavioural changes, confusion, fatigue, seizures, loss of consciousness), adrenergic symptoms (palpitations, tremors, anxiety), cholinergic symptoms (sweating, hunger), and diaphoresis are present. Increased heart rate and BP are mainly seen in individuals with repeated episodes.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male patient came with back pain and stiffness. He was found to have sacroiliitis on imaging and was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis. He is positive for an HLA marker. This marker positivity is also seen in _____.
  1. Psoriatic spondylitis
  2. Reactive arthritis due to Shigella
  3. Rheumatoid arthritis
  4. Behcet’s disease
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario of ankylosing spondylitis (AS), there will be positivity for HLA-B27. This marker positivity is also seen in psoriatic spondylitis (1) and reactive arthritis (2) due to Shigella.

HLA-B27 is also found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Psoriatic spondylitis: Some patients with psoriatic arthritis have axial joint involvement without peripheral involvement, which presents similarly to AS.
  • Reactive arthritis: Acute non-purulent arthritis occurs a few days after a systemic infection or an infection elsewhere in the body. It is usually seen following enteric or urogenital infection. Organisms causing these infections are Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, and Chlamydia.

Ankylosing spondylitis is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joint. It is more common in young males and strongly associates with HLA-B27.

Clinically, patients present with recurring backache, which worsens in the early morning or with inactivity and improves with exercise. Later, they develop fatigue, pain, joint swellings, and heel pain.

Extra-articular manifestations include uveitis, aortic incompetence, carditis, and apical lobe fibrosis.

X-ray findings:

  • Erosion of sacroiliac joints - sacroiliitis
  • Squaring of vertebrae and bamboo spine appearance

Other options:

  • Behcet's disease - HLA-B51 positive
  • Rheumatoid arthritis - HLA DR4 positive

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with resting tremors, slowness of movements, and a festinating gait. A clinical diagnosis of paralysis agitans was made. He, however, died later on due to other causes. At autopsy, a section of his brain was taken. What is true regarding the marked structure in this patient compared to that of normal individuals?

choices.text: Accumulation of synuclein and reduction in pigmentation
Accumulation of synuclein and increase in pigmentation
Accumulation of tau-proteins and reduction in pigmentation
Accumulation of tau-proteins  and increase in pigmentation

questions.solution:
The structure marked in this transverse section of the brain is substantia nigra. Degeneration of substantia nigra with the accumulation of synuclein and reduction in pigmentation is seen in Parkinson's disease (paralysis agitans) compared to normal individuals.

Substantia nigra is pigmented due to the presence of neuromelanin granules, which help in the synthesis of dopamine. In Parkinson's disease,  there is an absence/reduced pigmentation of the substantia nigra.

Bradykinesia, rigidity and resting tremor are classic features of Parkinson's disease. Because of motor disability, it is also referred to as paralysis agitans.

Note: Depression is often a comorbid finding with Parkinson's disease but is per se not due to damage to the substantia nigra.

questions.text: A man presents with pain and swelling of the right knee and ankle joint for one week with the following lesions on his soles. He gives a history of diarrhea 4 weeks ago. Which of the following is not commonly seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario with arthritis, preceding gastrointestinal infection and the above image showing keratoderma blennorrhagica are suggestive of reactive arthritis/Reiter's syndrome. Posterior uveitis is not seen in this condition. Instead, anterior uveitis is seen. 

Reactive arthritis (ReA) comes under the spectrum of seronegative spondyloarthropathies and is an acute asymmetric nonpurulent arthritis precipitated by an antecedent gastrointestinal or genitourinary infection. It usually occurs in young men and chronic ReA is associated with HLA-B27. Bacterial triggers for ReA are caused by Salmonella, Shigella, Yersinia, Campylobacter, Chlamydia trachomatis, Clostridium difficile, certain toxigenic Escherichia coli, Ureaplasma urealyticum, and Mycoplasma genitalium. There is a typical antecedent history of infection 1-4 weeks before the onset of arthritic symptoms.

Clinical features of ReA include constitutional symptoms like fever, malaise, fatigue and weight loss. There may be asymmetric arthritis with the involvement of a new joint within a few days. It involves large weight-bearing joints like knee and ankle. Dactylitis/sausage digit is a distinctive feature of reactive and psoriatic arthritis.

Extraarticular manifestations include keratoderma blennorrhagica presents as vesicles and pustules that lead to hyperkeratotic lesions/crusting on the palms and soles, enthesitis, anterior uveitis, and conjunctivitis. Circinate balanitis which consists of vesicles that rupture to form painless superficial erosions on the glans penis can be seen. Genitourinary symptoms like urethritis and prostatitis may occur. Cardiac conduction defects and aortic regurgitation may rarely occur.

Elevated ESR and CRP can be seen during the acute phase. Joint X-rays show juxta-articular osteoporosis, marginal erosions, loss of joint space, periostitis with new bone formation, and comma-shaped syndesmophytes.

High-dose NSAIDs have been shown to have some degree of benefit. Antibiotics during the antecedent infection may prevent the emergence of ReA. Intralesional glucocorticoids have been shown to benefit tendinitis and other enthesitic lesions.

questions.text: The patient whose hands are shown in the image below is developmentally delayed with a short, stocky build. Which of the following laboratory values is consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Considering the given options, based on the history and the image showing a short 4th metacarpal, the most likely diagnosis is pseudohypoparathyroidism. It is characterized by hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and high PTH. 

Pseudohypoparathyroidism occurs due to mutations in GNAS gene, leading to the formation of defective Gsα protein. This means that end-organ effects of PTH are hampered in patients suffering from pseudohypoparathyroidism. Even though PTH levels are high, it is not able to perform its normal function. Hypocalcemia is seen in these patients due to insufficient calcitriol production in the proximal renal tubules and consequent impaired intestinal calcium absorption. Urinary phosphate excretion is also impaired, causing hyperphosphatemia. 

Most patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism have characteristic skeletal features. These include short stature, early-onset obesity, round face, short metacarpals, and short metatarsals. This complex of skeletal abnormalities are referred to as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). Treatment of pseudohypoparathyroidism consists of a high dose of calcium and activated vitamin D (calcitriol).

questions.text: A young woman presents with a butterfly-shaped malar rash, a history of recurrent oral ulcers, and pain in multiple joints. Laboratory investigations show high titres of anti-nuclear antibodies, anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies, and anti-ribosomal P antibodies. She is diagnosed with systemic lupus erythematosus(SLE). What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE?
questions.solution:
The most common pulmonary manifestation of SLE is pleuritis, with or without pleural effusion.

SLE is an autoimmune disorder that results in damage to multiple organs and organ systems in the body, most commonly seen in women of reproductive age.

Acute or subacute cutaneous manifestations are photosensitivity and butterfly-shaped malar or maculopapular rash. Malar rash is characterized by a well-demarcated erythematous butterfly rash over the malar eminences with sparing of nasolabial folds. Chronic cutaneous manifestations are discoid rash and panniculitis. Other features are ulcerations in the oral mucosa and non-scarring alopecia.

Systemic features are  Synovitis involving ≥2 joints, pleuritis, pericarditis, lupus nephritis, Hemolytic anemia, Leukopenia Thrombocytopenia. Neurologic: seizures, psychosis, myelitis, neuropathy, confusional state

Laboratory investigations show positive antinuclear antibodies in the majority of cases. Positive anti-double-stranded DNA antibodies are specific for diagnosis. Positive antiphospholipid antibodies and low serum complement are also seen.

questions.text: In anterior spinal artery syndrome, which of the following is spared?
questions.solution:
In anterior spinal artery syndrome, the posterior columns are spared. Hence, vibration sense and proprioception are spared.

Anterior spinal artery syndrome involves the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord, affecting the corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. Features of this syndrome are paralysis and sensory impairments below the level of the lesion, which include impairment of pain and temperature sensation. Vibration sense and proprioception are spared. Autonomic control is also compromised, which leads to sexual, bladder and bowel dysfunction.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman presents with loss of memory, urinary incontinence, and decreased ability to perform day-to-day activities. She is oriented to time and place, but not to person. On gait assessment, you notice a hypokinetic magnetic gait. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The classic triad of dementia, hypokinetic magnetic gait, and urinary incontinence seen in this patient suggest normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is a communicating hydrocephalus caused by delayed resorption of cerebrospinal fluid. Meningeal scarring is seen in some patients, due to previous history of meningitis, subarachnoid hemorrhage, or head trauma.

It presents with the characteristic triad of

  • Dementia (mostly executive function),
  • Ataxic or apractic gait, and
  • Urinary incontinence (sometimes urgency too).

It is classified as idiopathic (primary) or symptomatic (secondary) occurring due to prior brain infection, injury, radiation, or hemorrhage. 

The etiology is poorly understood but is thought to be related to the hyperdynamic flow of CSF in the aqueduct, reduced compliance of the subarachnoid space, increased CSF pulse pressure, and reduced reabsorption of CSF. 

Diagnosis: 

  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the Sylvian fissures can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy due to the propped open (so-called “boxcarring”) appearance.
  • CSF parameters are normal except for the high range of pressure.
  • Another confirmatory test performed is the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) tap test, which shows marked improvement of symptoms with spinal fluid removal.

Treatment: Ventriculoperitoneal shunting: It is done to drain excess cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Complications of the shunting procedure include shunt obstruction, infection, intracerebral or intraventricular hemorrhage, malposition or breakage of the shunt, etc.

Other options:

Option B - Frontotemporal dementia is a group of syndromes that is characterized by frontotemporal lobar degeneration. The most common variant, the behavioral variant, presents with social and emotional dysfunction which manifests as apathy, disinhibition, compulsivity, loss of empathy, overeating, and may have deficits in executive control.

Option C - Parkinson disease is a neurodegenerative disease characterized by tremors at rest, rigidity, bradykinesia, gait dysfunction, postural instability, speech difficulty, swallowing impairment, and autonomic disturbances. 

Option D - Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is a degenerative brain disorder due to prions that leads to rapid mental deterioration, usually within a few months with associated myoclonus and behavioral changes.

questions.text: Which of the following findings would not be seen in a patient with SIADH?
questions.solution:
In a patient with (SIADH) syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone, increased plasma renin activity would not be seen. Plasma renin activity is suppressed in SIADH.

In SIADH, there is a failure of the body to increase the diuresis even when the water intake is more than the urinary loss. There is a slight increase in the total body water. This causes dilutional euvolemic hyponatremia and reduced serum osmolality (Option C). This causes a suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) (Option D) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels are increased because of excess fluid retention. Suppressed RAAS and increased ANP and BNP together work to minimise the increase in extracellular volume and prevent oedema by increasing the GFR (Option B). They also cause increased sodium excretion in the urine.

questions.text: A patient presents with loss of pain and temperature in a cape-like distribution in bilateral upper limbs with intact touch sensation. Cavitatory expansion of the central canal is noted on MRI. What is this condition most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with Syringomyelia, which is most commonly associated with Chiari type 1 malformation.

Syringomyelia is a progressive disease of the spinal cord in which there is an enlarging cavity in the cord. Syrinx cavities are acquired cavities of the cord in necrosed areas secondary to trauma, myelitis, and spinal cord tumors. It usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood with central cord symptoms. 

Most patients present with regional dissociated sensory loss of pain and temperature of the upper limbs. Touch and vibration senses are intact. The loss of sensation has a 'cape distribution' affecting the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms. Eventually, expansion of the cavity may lead to compression of the long tracts. This results in spasticity and weakness of the legs, bowel and bladder dysfunction, and Horner's syndrome. It is associated with Chiari type 1 malformation in which the cerebellar tonsils protrude through the foramen magnum and into the cervical spinal canal. 

MRI is used for the diagnosis. There is no satisfactory treatment for this condition. Symptomatic syrinx cavities secondary to trauma or infection are treated with a decompression and drainage procedure.

Other options:

Option A: Dandy walker malformation is a developmental anomaly characterized by a cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle, hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis, an enlarged posterior fossa, and an upward displacement of the cerebellum. 

Option C: Chiari type 2 malformation is the displacement of the medulla, the fourth ventricle, and cerebellar vermis through the foramen magnum. It is almost always associated with a myelomeningocele.

Option D: Chiari type 3 malformation is a rare anomaly characterized by herniation of the posterior fossa contents (cerebellum and/or the brainstem, occipital lobe, and fourth ventricle)

questions.text: Which of the following is a pre-hepatic cause of portal hypertension?
questions.solution:
Splenic vein thrombosis is a prehepatic cause of portal hypertension.

Splenic vein thrombosis can be caused by pancreatic inflammation or neoplasms (acute or chronic pancreatitis, pseudocysts, and carcinomas) that extend beyond the pancreas and invade the splenic vein. This thrombosis causes increased pressure in the splenic vein, leading to the formation of collaterals and, ultimately, gastric variceal haemorrhage (not esophageal varices).

Normal liver function tests, normal portal venous pressures, and splenomegaly are the features that differentiate portal hypertension due to splenic vein thrombosis from other forms of portal hypertension. In this type, the portal vein pressures remain normal since there is no obstruction of the hepatic venous vasculature.

Diagnosis is made by gastroscopy, liver function tests, ultrasound examination (with Doppler), and contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen. 

Treatment includes splenectomy and management of the primary pancreatic pathology.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with rheumatoid arthritis is to be started on hydroxychloroquine. Which of the following would you advise him prior to starting this drug?
questions.solution:
Prior to starting hydroxychloroquine therapy for rheumatoid arthritis, the patient should be advised to undergo an ocular examination.

Hydroxychloroquine is a disease-modifying drug used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis. Both chloroquine and its derivative hydroxychloroquine are melanotropic. They get concentrated in the melanin-containing structures of the eye, such as the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) and choroid. Significant retinal damage and visual deficits can develop in these patients, sometimes even without any signs on fundus examination. Therefore, baseline visual acuity testing and ocular examination are mandatory before starting hydroxychloroquine for a long duration.

As the retinopathy progresses, it leads to the formation of a bull's eye lesion, as shown in the picture below. It is characterized by pigment deposition in the foveola, surrounded by a ring of depigmented and atrophic RPE. This is further encircled by a hyperpigmented ring.

DMARDs that require tuberculosis screening (option B) include:

  • TNF-α inhibitors such as infliximab, etanercept, and adalimumab
  • JAK inhibitors such as tofacitinib and baricitinib
  • Interleukin-6 inhibitors such as tocilizumab
  • Anakinra
  • Abatacept

DMARDs that require evaluation for viral hepatitis include:

  • Leflunomide 
  • Methotrexate
  • Rituximab

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: A female patient presented to the emergency room with right-sided flank pain radiating to the groin for 1 day. Urinalysis shows crystals, as seen below. What are these crystals made up of?
questions.solution:
Dumbbell-shaped and envelope-shaped crystals in this patient are indicative of calcium oxalate stones.

The classic presentation for a patient with nephrolithiasis (renal calculi) is acute renal colic, which is the sudden onset of severe pain originating in the flank and radiating inferiorly and anteriorly (loin to groin). It is usually accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and hematuria. Urinalysis showing dumbbell and envelope-shaped crystals confirm that the kidney stones are made up of calcium oxalate. 

Risk factors for calcium oxalate stones:

  • Hyperparathyroidism (Causes hypercalcemia)
  • Hypercalciuria with normal serum calcium:
    • Hyperabsorption of calcium from the intestine (absorptive hypercalciuria)
    • Intrinsic impairment in renal tubular reabsorption of calcium (renal hypercalciuria)
    • Idiopathic fasting hypercalciuria with normal parathyroid function
  • Hyperoxaluria: Hereditary or acquired (intestinal malabsorption syndromes or excess intake of oxalate)
  • Hyperuricosuria
  • Hypocitraturia: Due to idiopathic causes, acidosis or chronic diarrhea.

There are four main types of calculi

  • Calcium stones (most common): composed of calcium oxalate or calcium oxalate mixed with calcium phosphate
  • Triple stones or struvite stones: composed of magnesium ammonium phosphate
  • Uric acid stones 
  • Cystine

Related Pearl: Microscopic Appearance of Various Stones

Xanthine, indinavir, and triamterene stones are radiolucent.

questions.text: An elderly woman, with a history of type 2 DM for 15 years, was initially treated with oral hypoglycemic agents and then with insulin for the last 3 years. To assess the consequent renal involvement,  which of the following tests would you perform on her?
questions.solution:
A test for urine microalbumin can be performed on this patient to assess the consequent renal involvement of diabetes. It is useful for detecting diabetic nephropathy at its incipient diabetic kidney disease stage. Microalbuminuria is defined as the excretion of albumin in the range of 30–300 mg/24 hr urine.

Microalbuminuria occurs about 5-10 years after the incidence of diabetes (Type I and Type II). It cannot be detected in urine dipsticks and usually requires a radioimmunoassay. It is a major risk factor for cardiovascular events and death in patients with type 2 diabetes. In many patients with type 2 diabetes, microalbuminuria succumbs to cardiovascular events before they progress to proteinuria or renal failure. Albuminuria remains the single most important predictor of a faster decline in GFR.

Diabetic nephropathy occurs as a result of glomerular hyperperfusion and renal hypertrophy. The following sequence of changes are seen in diabetic nephropathy:

  • Increased GFR 
  • Incipient diabetic nephropathy - microalbuminuria (30–300 mg/day albumin)
  • Overt diabetic nephropathy - macroalbuminuria ( >300 mg/day albumin)
  • End-stage renal disease 

The characteristic lesion of diabetic nephropathy is nodular or intercapillary glomerulosclerosis, also called Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules. It is pathognomonic for this condition. The following image shows Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules.

Other non-specific findings seen on biopsy include glomerular basement membrane thickening (highly sensitive) and diffuse glomerulosclerosis (most common pattern) due to diffuse mesangial thickening.

Diabetic nephropathy can be prevented by strict glycemic control. Associated hypertension and dyslipidemia should be promptly treated. Drugs like ACE inhibitors and ARBs can reverse albuminuria and glomerular filtration rate. Hypoglycemic drugs like sulfonylureas and metformin should not be used in advanced renal disease.

questions.text: All of the following drugs are used for chronic prophylaxis of migraine except:
questions.solution:
Sumatriptan has no role in the chronic prophylaxis of migraine. It is only used for the treatment of an acute episode.

Medication for chronic prophylaxis of migraine should be considered in patients with four or more attacks per month. The medications that are beneficial include:

  • Beta-blockers: propranolol, metoprolol
  • Anti-depressants: amitriptyline, venlafaxine
  • Anti-convulsants: valproate, topiramate
  • CGRP antagonists (monoclonal antibodies): eptinezumab, erenumab, fremanezumab, galcanezumab
  • Others: flunarizine, candesartan, memantine

Migraine is a primary headache disorder characterized by episodic headaches. The patients present with a unilateral, throbbing type of headache. The headache is preceded by a prodrome period characterized by mental fatigue, mood changes, and aura in the form of visual disturbances (zigzag lines in the visual field). The headache is associated with nausea, photophobia, and phonophobia.

Acute treatment of migraine is done with paracetamol and NSAIDs (naproxen, diclofenac). If this treatment does not bring relief, triptans such as sumatriptan or rizatriptan are given. They are agonists at 5HT1B/1D receptors and cause vasoconstriction in the intracranial blood vessels. Other drugs that can be given for the acute treatment of migraine are calcitonin-gene-related peptide (CGRP) receptor antagonists rimegepant and ubrogepant.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought with complaints of generalized edema. Urinalysis shows 3+ proteinuria. The serum albumin level is 2.4 g/dL. He responded within 2 weeks of treatment with prednisone. Which of the following statements is false regarding this disease?

choices.text: It is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children
All children require renal biospy for diagnosis
Majority of children achieve complete remission with steroids

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of minimal change in the disease type of nephrotic syndrome. In this condition, all children do not require renal biopsy for diagnosis.  

Minimal change disease is the most common cause (Option A) of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is more common in males and appears between 2 to 6 years of age. It is known as minimal change because, on renal biopsy, the glomerulus appears normal under light microscopy and shows no deposits in immunofluorescence. However, on electron microscopy, uniform and diffuse effacement of podocyte foot processes can be seen.

Clinically, the child presents with a history of edema that is initially noted around the eyes and gradually progresses into generalised edema. Hypertension and hematuria are uncommon.

Diagnosis can be made by urinalysis, which shows proteinuria ranging from 3+ to 4+ protein on urine dipstick and a spot urine protein/creatinine ratio (PCR) of >2. The urinary protein principally contains albumin; hence, it is known as selective proteinuria (Option B). Serum albumin levels are <2.5 g/dL, and there is an increase in serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels. 

Most children will respond to corticosteroid (prednisone/prednisolone) treatment and will achieve complete remission (Option D) (urine PCR <0.2 or <1+ protein on urine dipstick) within the initial 2-3 weeks of therapy. Failure to achieve remission after 6 weeks of steroids is known as steroid resistance. These patients require further evaluation, and only then is renal biopsy required. The usual cause of steroid resistance is focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

questions.text: An elderly man presents to the OPD with decreased urine output and facial puffiness. His estimated glomerular filtration rate was 42 mL/min/1.73 sq.m. What is the stage of his chronic kidney disease according to the KDIGO classification?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a GFR of 42 ml/min/1.73 m² indicates that the patient is in stage 3b according to KDIGO classification. 

Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes (KDIGO) stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD):

Stage GFR
Stage 1 > 90 ml/min/1.73 m²  
Stage 2 60 to 89 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 3a 45 to 59 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 3b 30 to 44 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 4 15 to 29 ml/min/1.73 m²
Stage 5 (end-stage renal disease) < 15 ml/min/1.73 m²

Renal function tests

A) GFR

GFR is the rate in millilitres per minute at which substances in plasma are filtered through the glomerulus. The normal GFR for an adult male is 90 to 120 mL/min

The characteristics of an ideal marker of GFR are as follows: 

  • It should appear endogenously in the plasma at a constant rate
  • It should be freely filtered at the glomerulus
  • It can be neither reabsorbed nor secreted by the renal tubule
  • It should not undergo extrarenal elimination.

Inulin is the most commonly used marker for GFR estimation.

B) Serum creatinine

Creatinine is the by-product of creatine phosphate in muscle. It is eliminated from the body by the kidney.
Normal range: 0.6 to 1.2 mg/dl

It is increased in 

  • Acute or chronic renal failure
  • ↑ Protein intake
  • High muscle mass

It is decreased in 

  • Low muscle mass
  • Pregnancy

C) Blood urea nitrogen

Urea is produced in the liver as the end product of protein metabolism and the urea cycle. 
Normal range: 5 to 20 mg/dl

Urea is elevated

    • Reduced GFR(Acute/chronic renal failure)
    • High protein diet
    • Upper GI bleeding
    • Dehydration

Urea is decreased in starvation, low-protein diet, and severe liver disease.

The ratio of BUN to creatinine can be useful to differentiate pre-renal from renal causes. In pre-renal disease, the ratio is close to 20:1, while in renal disease, it is closer to 10:1. However, Upper GI bleeding can be associated with a very high BUN to creatinine ratio (sometimes >30:1).

D) Uric acid

It is a catabolic metabolite of purines.

It is increased in

  • Acute renal failure
  • Tumor lysis syndrome
  • Lesch-Nyhan syndrome

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus presents with skin findings as shown in the image below.  On examination, he complained of pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot. On further questioning, the patient revealed that he was started on antidepressants recently. What could be the probable diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of diabetes mellitus, antidepressant intake, with pain in the calf on dorsiflexion of the foot(Positive Homan's sign indicating deep vein thrombosis), and the image showing necrolytic migratory rash is suggestive of glucagonoma.

Glucagonoma is a pancreatic islet cell tumor. It is a rare syndrome, with a classic presentation of the “4 D’s”: diabetes, dermatitis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and depression. It is a state of severe catabolism. Patients present with loss of weight, depletion of protein and fat stores, and vitamin deficiency.  The characteristic skin lesion seen in this condition is the necrolytic migratory erythema which occurs due to severe amino acid deficiency. Providing parental amino acids may help in the disappearance of skin lesions. 

Diagnosis of this condition is made by measuring fasting glucagon levels. A level of more than 1000pg/ml is diagnostic. (Normal - 100pg/ml) Management involves the correction of nutritional deficiencies with enteral nutrition. Octreotide can help reverse the catabolic state. DVT prophylaxis should be provided as soon as possible. Surgery can be done if the mass is resectable. 

Other options: 

Option A - Gastrinomas are islet cell tumors that produce large amounts of gastrin. This gastrin does not respond to the normal feedback mechanism and is not suppressed by high luminal pH. Patients with gastrinomas present with abdominal pain and diarrhea. 

Option B - Insulinomas are the most common pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. They are characterized by symptoms of hypoglycemia, low plasma glucose at the time of symptoms, and relief of symptoms on glucose consumption. This is known as the Whipple's triad.

Option D - VIPoma is a neuroendocrine tumor that arises from the pancreatic D2 islet cells. It is characterized by watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, and achlorhydria. It is also referred to as pancreatic cholera.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient with chronic kidney disease is planned for dialysis treatment. All of the following statements are true about dialysis except.

choices.text: Uremic encephalopathy can be an indication of dialysis
Cardiovascular related deaths are more common among those on dialysis than transplant recipients
The most common acute complication of hemodialysis is hypotension
Peritoneal dialysis is executed by creating an anastomosis of an artery to a vein

questions.solution:
Hemodialysis, not peritoneal dialysis is executed by creating an anastomosis of an artery to a vein. In peritoneal dialysis, a peritoneal catheter is used to gain access into the peritoneal cavity to carry out dialysis.

Dialysis is a form of renal replacement therapy. Here the kidney's function of blood filtration is supplemented with artificial equipment to remove excess water, solutes, and toxins.

Dialysis broadly has three types that include hemodialysis, peritoneal dialysis and continuous renal replacement therapy.

Indications for dialysis include: 

  • Refractory metabolic acidosis that has failed to respond to medical treatment
  • Refractory hyperkalemia 
  • Extracellular volume expansion despite diuretic therapy
  • Uremic symptoms (encephalopathy) (Option A)
  • eGFR <10 mL/min per 1.73 m2 
  • Any toxic ingestions

Contraindications for dialysis include inability to secure vascular access, needle phobia, cardiac failure and coagulopathy.

For patients with ESKD(End-stage kidney disease) in the long term, cardiovascular disorders are considered the major cause of death. Notably, cardiovascular-related deaths are more common among those on dialysis than transplant recipients (Option B).

The most common acute complication of hemodialysis is intradialytic hypotension (Option C).

A man with chronic alcoholism presents with abdominal distension. Laboratory tests show that the AST: ALT ratio is 3:1. What is the possible mechanism behind this finding?

questions.solution:
The possible mechanism behind the finding of AST:ALT ratio of 3:1 in a chronic alcoholic patient is the deficiency of vitamin B6, leading to a decrease in ALT level.

Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease

Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate, which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.

Important liver function tests

  1. Serum bilirubin - the normal levels of serum total bilirubin is between 1-1.5mg/dL, out of which direct bilirubin is less than 0.3mg/dL. If the levels of indirect bilirubin are more than 85% of the total, then it is considered to be indirect hyperbilirubinemia. Important causes of indirect hyperbilirubinemia are hemolytic anemias, Crigler-Najjar, and Gilbert’s syndromes. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in the liver or biliary tract disease. In the majority of liver diseases, both conjugated and unconjugated are elevated.
  2. Liver enzymes- aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) are the sensitive indicators of liver injury. Alkaline phosphatase and 5′-nucleotidase are the markers for cholestasis.
  3. Serum albumin - it is synthesized exclusively by hepatocytes. The level of albumin decreases in decreased liver function. However, the half-life of albumin is 18-20 days. Therefore it is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction. It mainly indicates chronic hepatic dysfunction.
  4. Coagulation factors - with the exception of actor VIII, other blood clotting factors are synthesized in the liver. In contrast to albumin, they have a very small half-life ranging from 6 h for factor VII to 5 days for fibrinogen. Therefore, it can be helpful in diagnosing acute parenchymal diseases also.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient who has type 2 diabetes comes with complaints of nausea, bloating, and early satiety. She also has had an 8 kg weight loss over 2 months. What test is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a known history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and complaints of nausea, early satiety, weight loss and bloating most likely has developed diabetic gastroparesis, a form of diabetic autonomic neuropathy. The best test to confirm the diagnosis is a gastric emptying study also known as gastric scintigraphy.

Diabetic gastroparesis occurs due to autonomic neuropathy caused by chronic high blood glucose levels. This affects gastric motility and decreases the number of contractions, leading to food retention in the stomach over extended periods of time. 

Any mechanical obstructions should be ruled out while evaluating a patient with such symptoms. Initially, an upper GI endoscopy is done. This can show retained food in the stomach without any mechanical obstruction. 

The confirmatory test is a radiolabeled four-hour gastric emptying study. 

Treatment:

  • The first step is lifestyle modifications including strict glycemic control. 
  • Patients should be encouraged to have smaller frequent meals. 
  • Carbonated beverages and fat and fibre-containing foods have to be avoided. 
  • Pharmacotherapy is with drugs that increase gastrointestinal motility like erythromycin, metoclopramide, ondansetron and promethazine. 

Other Options:

Options A and B: USG abdomen and CT Abdomen are done in cases of suspected mechanical obstruction and malignancies. This patient with her history of Diabetes mellitus most likely has diabetic gastroparesis.

Option C: D Xylose absorption test is done to check for normal intestinal function. It is used in the evaluation of celiac disease.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with acute onset of blurry vision in the right eye since morning. She also complains of pain on movement of the right eye for two days.  She gives a history of weakness in her right upper limb one month ago, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, the following finding is elicited. What is the next step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a Relative Afferent Pupillary Defect. This finding along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of an acute relapse of multiple sclerosis, and methylprednisolone is used for immediate management.

The patients' symptoms of blurry vision and pain on movement of the eye are suggestive of optic neuritis. The above image shows a relative afferent pupillary defect (Marcus-Gunn pupil) on the swinging flashlight test. On shining the torchlight to the normal eye, both the pupils constrict due to intact direct and indirect light reflexes to the stimulus carried by the normal optic nerve. On swinging and shining the torchlight to the diseased eye, both the pupils appear to dilate. This is due to the damage to the optic nerve carrying the afferent fibers in the diseased eye, resulting in the loss of direct and indirect light reflexes. This phenomenon is seen in cases of unilateral optic nerve damage, like in this patient's optic neuritis.

High-dose intravenous methylprednisolone 1000 mg daily for five days is the drug of choice for acute exacerbation of multiple sclerosis.

Other options:

Options B and C: Plasma exchange can be used for an acute relapse of MS but is not the first preferred treatment. It can be used along with steroids or in case of poor response to steroids. Beta Interferon can be used in relapsing MS to slow the attack rate and reduce disability. It is not suitable for an acute episode of optic myelitis.

Option D: Acyclovir is an antiviral and is not effective in the treatment of optic neuritis due to acute MS.

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have renal tubular acidosis. His lab parameters show elevated potassium levels and metabolic acidosis. Identify the correct pair describing the diagnosis from the following options.

choices.text: Renal tubular acidosis 2 - impaired HCO3- reabsorption
Renal tubular acidosis 1 - impaired H+ secretion

questions.solution:
Renal tubular acidosis 4 - hypoaldosteronism is the correct pair that explains the diagnosis of the given patient.

RTA 4 (hyperkalemic renal tubular acidosis) is associated with aldosterone deficiency or resistance, leading to impaired potassium excretion, leading to hyperkalemia and metabolic acidosis.

RTA refers to a group of disorders in which there is impaired tubular transport of H+ and/or HCO3- despite relatively well-preserved renal function. There are 4 types:

  • Type I - impaired H+ secretion (distal), leading to decreased HCO3- production
  • Type II - impaired HCO3- reabsorption (proximal)
  • Type III - carbonic anhydrase deficiency causing defects in the transport of both H+ and HCO3- (mixed)
  • Type IV - hypoaldosteronism (hyperkalemic)

Other options:

Option B: RTA 2 (Proximal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition involves impaired bicarbonate reabsorption in the proximal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to urinary losses of potassium.

Option C: RTA 4 causes features of hypoaldosteronism and not hyperaldosteronism. So, this option is incorrect.

Option D: RTA 1 (Distal Renal Tubular Acidosis): This condition is characterized by impaired acid secretion in the distal renal tubules, leading to metabolic acidosis. Hypokalemia can occur due to the compensatory secretion of potassium to maintain electroneutrality.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient comes with complaints of recurrent palpitations. On physical examination, he has small gonads and a receding hairline. When the physician shakes hands with him, he has difficulty releasing the hand. What is the likely etiology of his disease?
questions.solution:
The patient's clinical features of palpitations with small gonads, a receding hairline and difficulty in releasing hands make a diagnosis of myotonic dystrophy likely.  This occurs due to a CTG trinucleotide repeat on chromosome 19.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused by CTG trinucleotide repeat in the DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1) and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block or other conduction anomalies. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1. However, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1 and DM2 shows internalised nuclei seen in individual muscle fibres and the presence of several atrophic fibres with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 to help in reducing myotonia.

Other Options:

Option B: Motor neuron atrophy can be seen in conditions like Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Option C: Neuromuscular junction dysfunctions are affected in myasthenia gravis and Lambert-Eaton syndrome. 

Option D: Mitochondrial DNA defect is seen in Hereditary Leber's optic neuropathy.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient came with complaints of her hands turning very pale on exposure to cold for one month. The skin on her face and fingers is thickened and tight, and she has dilated capillaries over her face. She has a history of GERD. On investigation, she was found to have the following immunofluorescence pattern. Which of the following antibodies is most specific to this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario featuring the Raynaud phenomenon, GERD, telangiectasias and tightening of the skin in the face and hands is suggestive of CREST syndrome/ limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis, and anti-centromere antibodies are most specific for this disease. 

CREST syndrome consists of the following:

  • Calcinosis cutis
  • Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • Esophageal dysmotility
  • Sclerodactyly
  • Telangiectasia

Systemic sclerosis (SSc) is a chronic autoimmune disease. Progressive fibrosis due to the deposition of extracellular matrix components in different tissues and organs is the prominent feature of SSc. 

The characteristic features of SSc are vascular damage, inflammation, and the presence of specific autoantibodies. 

SSc is classified into two based on the extent of skin involvement.

  • Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis / CREST syndrome
  • Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

In limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), fibrosis in the skin of acral parts of the body, like the face and limbs (distal to elbow and knee), takes place. Skin fibrosis in limited type has a slow progression, but microcirculation disturbances like Raynaud's phenomenon start long before the skin symptoms and are associated with the involvement of the lungs and esophagus. 

Since it has late and slow organ involvement, it is associated with a good prognosis with a 10-year survival of over 90%. 

Antinuclear antibodies (ANA) are present in 90 - 95% of cases with SSc.

Autoantibodies specific to limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis include,

  • Anti- centromere
  • Anti-Th/To
  • Anti-U1-RNP
  • Anti-hUBF

Management is based on disease-modifying and organ-specific drugs. For peripheral vasculopathy and digital ulcers, calcium channel blockers like nifedipine amlodipine are used, and for refractory cases, phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors are recommended.

Intravenous prostanoids are used for the healing process of digital ulcers and the improvement of microcirculation. The commonly used immunosuppressants for skin fibrosis are methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and mycophenolate mofetil. When these drugs are ineffective or contraindicated, low-dose glucocorticosteroids or rituximab (anti-CD20) are used.

questions.text: Hypercalcemia in a patient with sarcoidosis is due to:

choices.text: Production of 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D by the granuloma

questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia and/or hypercalciuria occur in 10% of patients with sarcoidosis. The mechanism of abnormal calcium metabolism is due to the increased production of 1,25-dihydroxy-vitamin D by the granuloma itself. This results in increased intestinal absorption of calcium, leading to hypercalcemia with a suppressed PTH level. Increased Vitamin D from diet or sunlight exposure may exacerbate this problem.

Sarcoidosis is a multisystemic inflammatory disease characterized by the presence of noncaseating granulomas. These granulomas express 1-alpha hydroxylase that converts 25-hydroxyvitamin D to 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, leading to increased intestinal absorption of calcium which results in hypercalcemia.

The lungs are most commonly affected in sarcoidosis, and the patients commonly present with cough and dyspnea. The involvement of the right paratracheal, right hilar, and left hilar lymph nodes leads to a characteristic pattern of lymph node enlargement known as the Garland triad, 1-2-3 sign, or pawnbroker's sign.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with HIV comes with complaints of frothy urine and facial swelling. He has a past history of IV heroin use. His BP is 150/98 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a past history of heroin abuse and current HIV status, his current symptoms of frothy urine and edema of the face make focal segmental glomerulosclerosis(FSGS) the likely diagnosis.

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

These patients present with hypertension, edema, and nephrotic range proteinuria. 

Treatment: Prednisone, immunosuppressants to reduce the kidney injury. ACEis and ARBs to control the hypertension.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old female presents with complaints of double vision. She has noticed that as the day progresses her diplopia increases and is maximum when she is reading her book at night. Additionally, she has had trouble swallowing chunks of meat for the past few days. Physical examination reveals normal deep tendon reflexes and mild bilateral ptosis. Placing an ice pack over her eyes significantly decreases the ptosis. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in this patient?

a - Aminoglycosides
b - Metformin
c - Ciprofloxacin
d - Propanolol
e - Magnesium hydroxide
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes a case of myasthenia gravis. Aminoglycosides, ciprofloxacin, beta-blockers, and magnesium hydroxide must be avoided in myasthenia gravis (a,c,d,e).

Drugs that may aggravate myasthenia gravis are

  • Antibiotics like aminoglycosides, quinolones, and macrolides
  • Beta-blockers
  • Botulinum toxin
  • Local anesthetics
  • Magnesium
  • Non–depolarising muscle relaxants
  • Penicillamine
  • Quinine derivatives

Aminoglycosides have to be avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis. It blocks Ca2+ mediated exocytosis of acetylcholine from the presynaptic membrane in the neuromuscular junction. The decrease in ACh levels aggravates myasthenia gravis. Aminoglycosides can also have a direct inhibitory effect on post-synaptic acetylcholine receptors. 

The common antacid Digene contains Mg(OH)2 and must be avoided in myasthenia gravis.

Myasthenia Gravis-

It is an autoimmune disorder of the neuromuscular junction. Autoantibodies are directed against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (AChR)(more common) or muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase (MuSK).

Presentation-

  • Fluctuating muscle weakness
  • Weakness is worse with continued use
  • Ocular symptoms(most common presenting symptoms) - ptosis, diplopia
  • Bulbar symptoms -dysphagia, dysarthria, fatigable chewing
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Ice-pack test - ice pack improves ptosis(decreases activity of acetylcholinesterase this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft_
  • Edrophonium chloride (Tensilon test) - edrophonium is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, this increases the amount of acetylcholine in the synaptic cleft.

Diagnosis-

AChR antibodies, MuSK antibodies, LRP4 antibodies, single-fiber electromyography, repetitive nerve stimulation.

Treatment -

Pyridostigmine, azathioprine, thymectomy

questions.text: A 51-year-old female is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. Her speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. She says, "walk dog", and nods her head when asked if she meant to say, "I want to take the dog for a walk". The comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what she wants to say. Other neurological examination findings are within normal limits. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere
Posterior temporal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Posterior parietal and temporal lobes, non-dominant hemisphere
Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus, dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
The patient described above has Broca’s aphasia (WA). This usually occurs as a result of vascular damage to Broca's motor speech area in the inferior frontal gyrus due to occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA).

A lesion in this region leads to motor/Broca's aphasia. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is impoverished in function words that contribute to the syntax but is enriched in meaningful nouns and verbs. However, comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what he wants to say.

For example, a patient with Broca's aphasia may say, "walk dog" instead of "I want to take the dog for a walk". Speech therapy in Broca's aphasia is more successful than in Wernicke’s aphasia.

Aphasia is an acquired disorder of language due to damage to the brain. It occurs either secondary to brain injury or degeneration and involves the left cerebral hemisphere to a greater extent. Both written and spoken communication are affected. Audio-visual understanding is also deranged.

There is difficulty in finding words, leading to poorly understood content for the listener. These patients also find it difficult to repeat sentences and name things properly. Aphasia is diagnosed in patients with deficits in the formal aspects of language, such as word-finding, word choice, comprehension, spelling, or grammar.

Many specific aphasic syndromes have been reported. The most common are Broca, Wernicke, conduction, and global aphasias. Other are non-peri-sylvian aphasias that include anomic, transcortical motor, transcortical sensory, and mixed transcortical, sometimes called the isolation of the speech area syndrome.

Wernicke’s aphasia occurs as a result of damage in the posterior temporal and parietal regions, which are supplied by the lower division of the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A woman with a negative urine pregnancy test presents to you with galactorrhea. She is taking metoprolol for blood pressure control. Her prolactin levels are 35 mcg/L, and TSH and free T4 levels are reduced. What is the most likely cause for her elevated prolactin levels?
questions.solution:
The most likely cause for her elevated prolactin levels is pituitary stalk compression.

Dopamine is a prolactin-release inhibitory factor, and disruption of the pituitary stalk leads to impaired transport of dopamine to lactotrophs and, thus, loss of inhibition. This leads to an increase in prolactin levels.

This diagnosis is also supported by the fact that there is also secondary hypothyroidism due to decreased TSH and free T4. This is because TRH stimulates TSH secretion from the pituitary. Loss of stalk function will lead to reduced influence of TRH on TSH.

Other options:

Option B: Prolactinoma is generally diagnosed at prolactin levels of >200 mcg/L.

Option C: Primary hypothyroidism would have increased TSH along with a decrease in free T4 levels.

Option D: Metoprolol does not affect prolactin levels.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male is being evaluated for high blood pressure noted on multiple occasions. Investigations reveal metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and suppressed renin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, a young patient with hypertension, metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, and reduced renin and aldosterone levels is suggestive of Gordon syndrome (pseudohypoaldosteronism).

Other options:

Option A: Liddle’s syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC gene, which codes for the epithelial sodium channels present in the kidney. Hypertension is the result of increased sodium retention through the ENaC channel and volume expansion. Volume expansion suppresses renin and aldosterone secretion, leading to hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis.

Option B: Gitelman syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder due to a loss of function mutation in the thiazide-sensitive Na+-Cl– cotransporter of the distal convoluted tubule. It is characterised by hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypomagnesemia and hypocalciuria with low blood pressure.

Option D:  Bartter syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder occurring due to defects in various genes involved in the regulated Na+, K+, and Cl– transport by the thick ascending loop of Henle. There is extracellular fluid volume depletion with low or normal blood pressure. It is characterised by metabolic alkalosis, hypokalemia, hypochloremia, and hypercalciuria.
