questions.text: A patient with a history of bilateral adrenalectomy has been diagnosed with Nelson's syndrome. Which of the following is not associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
Nelson’s syndrome is not associated with hyperpituitarism. Instead, Nelson’s syndrome often leads to hypopituitarism due to compression of normal pituitary tissue by the growing corticotroph adenoma. 

Nelson's syndrome is a rare complication of total bilateral adrenalectomy (TBA). TBA is a procedure used to control hypercortisolism in Cushing's disease (due to ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma) when resection of the primary tumour is not possible.

The loss of feedback inhibition of the hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis following TBA increases Corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH). This leads to stimulation of ACTH-secreting corticotroph cells, causing enlargement of the original pituitary tumour or the formation of a new one.

Nelson's syndrome is associated with a clinical triad of:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Excessive ACTH secretion
  • Corticotroph adenoma

Screening is done with fasting plasma ACTH levels and MRI brain is performed at regular intervals. Prophylactic pituitary irradiation may be recommended to prevent its incidence. The primary treatment is transsphenoidal surgery. Patients will also require life-long glucocorticoid replacement, as they do not produce cortisol.

The use of steroidogenic inhibitors in the treatment of Cushing's disease has decreased the need for bilateral adrenalectomy these days.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presented to OPD for routine health checkup. Investigations were performed and are given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?

Serum bilirubin: 3 mg/dl
Direct bilirubin: 0.2 mg/dl
Indirect bilirubin: 2.8 mg/dl
AST: 40 U/L
ALT: 25 U/L
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, isolated elevation of unconjugated (Indirect) bilirubin in an asymptomatic post-pubertal patient points towards the diagnosis of Gilbert syndrome.

Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome have elevated levels of conjugated bilirubin. Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II has similar laboratory findings, however, it usually presents in the neonatal period.

Serum bilirubin is the breakdown product of heme-containing proteins. The normal serum total bilirubin levels are between 1-1.5 mg/dL. There are two types of bilirubin:

  • Conjugated (Direct) bilirubin: It is water-soluble and is excreted by the kidney. The normal upper limit is 0.3 mg/dl. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in the liver or biliary tract disease.
  • Unconjugated (Indirect) bilirubin: Unconjugated bilirubin always binds to albumin in the serum and is not filtered by the kidney. Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia is seen in hemolytic anemias, Crigler-Najjar, and Gilbert’s syndromes. 

However, in the majority of liver diseases, both conjugated and unconjugated are elevated.

Liver enzymes

  • Aspartate aminotransferase (AST):
    Normal range: 7-56 U/L
    AST is found in multiple organs and is a less specific marker.
  • Alanine aminotransferase (ALT):
    Normal range: 0 to 35 U/L
     ALT is specifically found in the liver and is a more specific indicator of liver injury.

The AST: ALT ratio can be interpreted as follows:

AST: ALT Condition
<1 Chronic viral hepatitis, Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease
>1 Cirrhosis
>2:1

Suggestive of alcoholic liver disease

Alcohol intake is associated with the deficiency of pyridoxal phosphate, which in turn leads to decreased levels of ALT enzyme. So, AST>ALT.
>3:1 Highly suggestive of alcoholic liver disease
  • Alkaline phosphatase and 5′-nucleotidase are the markers for cholestasis.

Serum albumin

Albumin is synthesized exclusively by hepatocytes. The level of albumin decreases in decreased liver function. However, the half-life of albumin is 18-20 days. Therefore it is not a good indicator of acute or mild hepatic dysfunction like viral hepatitis, drug-induced hepatotoxicity, etc. It mainly indicates chronic hepatic dysfunction.

Serum globulins

Serum globulins include γ globulin produced by B lymphocytes and α and β globulins produced primarily in hepatocytes. γ Globulins are increased in chronic liver diseases, such as chronic hepatitis and cirrhosis.

Coagulation factors

All the blood clotting factors are synthesized in the liver except factor VIII. In contrast to albumin, they have a very short half-life. Therefore, it can be helpful in diagnosing acute parenchymal diseases.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true about Na+ imbalance?

Statement A: Rapid correction of hyponatremia leads to central pontine myelinolysis.

Statement B: Rapid correction of hypernatremia can be done safely.

Statement C: Sodium deficit is calculated as (target sodium concentration-sodium before correction) x 0.6 x Body weight in kg.

Statement D: Hypernatremia is seen in SIADH.
questions.solution:
Statements A and C are true about Na+ imbalance.

Statement A: Rapid correction of hyponatremia at a rate of more than 8–10 mM in 24 hours or 18 mM in 48 hours causes hypertonic stress, leading to apoptosis and cell death. It causes central pontine myelinolysis (CPM) which presents as quadriplegia, mutism, and rigidity after treatment and can present a few days after the initial correction.

Prevention of CPM depends on therapeutic guidelines employed for the restoration of severe hyponatremia; the guidelines should aim for gradual correction, i.e. at a rate of ≤10 mmol/L (10 mEq/L) within 24 hours and ≤20 mmol/L (20 mEq/L) within 48 hours.

Statement C: The formula for calculating sodium deficit is as follows.

(target sodium concentration-sodium before correction) x 0.6 x Body weight in kg.

Statement B: Rapid correction of hypernatremia can be done safely is a false statement. Hypernatremia must be corrected slowly by replacing the calculated free water deficit over 48 h, in order to avoid cerebral edema. The plasma Na+ concentration should be corrected by no more than 10 mM per day.

Statement D: Hypernatremia is seen in SIADH is a false statement. SIADH is characterized by impaired water excretion leading to hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia.

questions.text: An elderly man presented to the OPD with painful, reddish swelling of his left great toe. Synovial fluid examination showed negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. Which of the following is true about the acute cases of this condition?

choices.text: Martel’s sign is seen on the x-ray
Pink colour crystals are on the synovial fluid examination
Serum uric acid levels can be normal
Allopurinol is used to terminate the acute attacks

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the presentation of painful, red swelling of the great toe with synovial fluid examination showing negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals suggests gout. Normal serum uric acid levels can be seen in acute gout.

Gout is a metabolic disease that is characterized by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and connective tissue. It is more common in males.

It usually presents as monoarthritis that may be acute and episodic or chronic. Acute gout presents with a red, hot, swollen, and extremely tender joint on examination. The metatarsophalangeal joint of the great toe is the most frequently involved joint.

Synovial fluid analysis of joint aspirate is diagnostic and shows the following features:

  • Increased leukocyte count with a neutrophilic predominance
  • Negatively birefringent crystals on polarized light microscopy of the synovial fluid

Antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide and ethambutol cause hyperuricemia by inhibiting uric acid excretion in the kidney.

Monosodium urate crystals as seen on polarised light microscopy:

Other options

Option A: Martel sign is a radiological finding seen in chronic gout and not in acute cases.

Option B: Yellow colour crystals are seen in gout on the synovial fluid examination.

Option D: Allopurinol is not used in terminating acute attacks of gout and instead, used to prevent further attacks by reducing uric acid levels. Hence, it is mainly preferred in chronic gout.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with chronic kidney disease presented to the OPD with painful, reddish swelling of his left great toe. Synovial fluid examination showed negatively birefringent needle-shaped crystals. Which of the following is contraindicated when treating this patient?
questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and gout, Ibuprofen is contraindicated as it is nephrotoxic. NSAIDs, including ibuprofen, can worsen kidney function, leading to further deterioration in patients with CKD. 

Other options: Other treatments for gout, such as colchicine, allopurinol, and prednisolone, can be used but may require careful dose adjustments to avoid toxicity due to impaired kidney function.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient is brought to the emergency room with complaints of altered sensorium and abdominal pain. She appears dehydrated. Investigations revealed pH - 7.00, blood sugar level- 500 mg/dL, and ketonuria. She is started on IV insulin with Potassium infusion. Which of the following parameters can be used to assess the recovery of the patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with severe dehydration, hyperglycemia, ketonuria, and metabolic acidosis(pH-7.00) suggests a diagnosis of diabetic ketoacidosis(DKA) likely due to undiagnosed Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus. The serum anion gap is a test that can be used to measure the recovery of the patient.

In DKA, due to the absence of insulin, there is a decrease in glucose uptake in cells in the body leading to a state of starvation. This leads to an increase in levels of glucagon and ketone bodies to provide a constant source of energy to the cells including the myocardial and neural tissue. Increased serum ketones widen the anion gap which is why DKA is an Anion gap metabolic acidosis.  Serum anion gap can be used to measure the response to treatment and also helps in planning further management. As the patient receives insulin, there is a cessation of production of ketoacids and this in turn leads to the normalisation of the serum anion gap.

In DKA, the insulin-to-glucagon ratio is decreased which promotes gluconeogenesis, glycogenolysis, and ketone body formation in the liver. Ketone bodies exist as ketoacids at physiologic pH which are neutralized by bicarbonate. As bicarbonate stores are depleted, metabolic acidosis ensues. Increased lactic acid production also contributes to acidosis.

The diagnostic biochemical criteria for DKA include:

  • Hyperglycemia (>200 mg/dL)
  • Venous pH <7.3 or plasma/serum bicarbonate <15 mmol/L 
  • Ketonemia (beta-hydroxybutyrate [BOHB] >3 mmol/L) and ketonuria

Signs of ketoacidosis: 

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, heavy, non-labored rapid breathing)
  • Fruity breath odor (acetone)
  • Prolonged Q-T interval
  • Diminished neurocognitive function
  • Coma

Management: Based on the ISPAD guidelines, the initial management includes management of the airway, breathing, and circulation and fluid replacement with an IV bolus of 10 mL/kg normal saline over 1 hour. This is followed by an IV insulin infusion of 0.1 U/kg/hour.

questions.text: Which of the following is most consistent with active viral replication in a patient with chronic hepatitis B infection?

choices.text: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgM positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg negative, Anti-HBs positive, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, Anti-HBe negative
HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg negative, Anti-HBe negative

questions.solution:
Chronic hepatitis B with active viral replication has the following serological findings: HBsAg positive, Anti-HBs negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive, HBeAg positive, and Anti-HBe negative.

After a person is infected with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serologic marker to increase in level is HBsAg. It becomes detectable in the serum between 1-12 weeks. It becomes undetectable 1–2 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once the HBsAg becomes undetectable, anti-HBs antibody starts rising in serum and remains detectable indefinitely thereafter. The gap between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is called the window period. If HBsAg persists beyond 6 months, it is likely to be chronic hepatitis B.

HBcAg is located inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. As a result, HBcAg is not commonly detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection since naked core particles are not found in the bloodstream. Conversely, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after the emergence of HBsAg, usually within 1-2 weeks. Anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker useful for the identification of HBV infection during the window period. Initially, the anti-HBc is of IgM variety, but in chronic infections, it is of IgG class.

HBeAg appears shortly after the appearance of HBsAg. Its appearance correlates with high levels of virus replication. Anti-HBe correlates with a period of lower infectivity. In chronic active hepatitis, HBeAg persists and anti-HBe does not appear.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presented with headaches and palpitations for the past 3 hours. She had a history of seizures in the past. Her serum and urine are positive for metanephrines. Any of the following may be associated with her underlying condition except:
questions.solution:
In this child presenting with headache, palpitations, and a positive urinary metanephrine test, the probable diagnosis is pheochromocytoma. It can be associated with plexiform neurofibroma (NF 1), Cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastomas (VHL syndrome) or Carotid body tumour/ glomus tumor  (Familial Paraganglioma  Syndrome). However, Bilateral vestibular schwannomas are seen in neurofibromatosis type 2 (NF 2), which is not typically seen in association with pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumour derived from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. It can be sporadical or hereditary. Hereditary pheochromocytoma occurs in association with syndromes such as Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2), familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome, Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome, and neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF 1).

Pheochromocytoma has a variable presentation and is called 'the great masquerader’. This is because of the variability in the catecholamine secreted by different types of pheochromocytoma.

It may present as a classic triad of intermittent headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating, along with hypertension. The patient can also present with anxiety, panic attacks, nausea, abdominal pain, weight loss, and weakness.

Precipitants of pheochromocytoma include:

  • Surgery
  • Pregnancy
  • Exercise, stress or trauma
  • Medications such as steroids, metoclopramide and tricyclic antidepressants.

The cut section of pheochromocytoma is greyish-pink with areas of haemorrhage and necrosis. Histologically, there is a classical Zellballen pattern with nests of neuroendocrine chief cells and peripheral glia-like sustentacular cells. The chief cells are positive for chromogranin and synaptophysin, while the sustentacular cells are positive for S100.

The image below shows tumour cells:

  • (a) with a distinct ‘‘pepper and salt’’ chromatin of the nucleolus and “Zellballen” or nesting pattern
  • (b) Strong chromogranin-stained pattern
  • (c) Synaptophysin intermediately stained pattern
  • (d) Ki-67 poorly stained pattern

Diagnosis of pheochromocytoma requires biochemical testing followed by imaging.

  • Urinary and plasma levels of catecholamines and metanephrines are some of the most sensitive and specific tests for the detection of pheochromocytoma.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice for localising the tumour since the contrast used in CT scans can precipitate paroxysms.
  • MIBG Scintigraphy and PET Scans like Ga- DOTATE, DOPA- or FDG- PET uses radioactive tracers to identify the primary tumour as well as the extra-adrenal tumours and metastases.

The image given below shows a coronal section of the abdomen with a left-sided pheochromocytoma over the left kidney.

The image given below shows a left-sided pheochromocytoma, as seen from MIBG Scintigraphy. The thyroid and bladder are also seen due to the normal physiologic uptake.

Treatment of pheochromocytoma includes:

  • Phenoxybenzamine is the drug of choice which causes irreversible and non-selective alpha-1 receptor blockade, but it needs to be stopped 48 hours preoperatively
  • Other alpha-blockers like selective alpha-1 receptor antagonists, namely, Prazosin and Doxazosin, are also used for the management of hypertension.
  • Beta-blockers are used to control tachycardia after adequate alpha blockade is achieved. This is to prevent unrestricted alpha-mediated vasoconstriction.
  • Surgical resection of the tumour is the definitive treatment. Postoperative hypovolemia, hypotension and hypoglycemia are commonly seen.
  • Malignant pheochromocytoma requires surgical resection and Averbuch's chemotherapy regimen with the use of Mitotane as an adjuvant or for palliation.
  • Lifelong yearly follow-up should be done postoperatively.

Other options:

Option B: Plexiform neurofibroma is a characteristic finding of neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF 1), along with cafe au lait macules, Lisch nodules, pheochromocytoma, axillary and inguinal freckling.

Option C: Cerebellar and spinal haemangioblastomas are associated with von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) syndrome along with pheochromocytoma, bilateral kidney tumours and pancreatic tumours. 

Option D: Carotid body glomus tumour and extra-adrenal paraganglioma are characteristic of familial paraganglioma (PG) syndrome.
